title: Using radioactive drugs to see inside your body - Pedro Brugarolas

multiple-choice.question: What is the radioactive form of glucose used in PET scans?

options.label: A
options.text: FDG

options.label: B
options.text: PET

options.label: C
options.text: PET scanner

options.label: D
options.text: Positron emission

multiple-choice.question: What is the purpose of a cyclotron in the production of PET tracers?

options.label: A
options.text: To accelerate charged particles like protons

options.label: B
options.text: To detect the spread of cancer

options.label: C
options.text: To create a 3D map of the tracer's distribution

options.label: D
options.text: To attach radioactive fluorine to different molecules

multiple-choice.question: What happens when a proton slams into a heavier oxygen atom in the target of a cyclotron?

options.label: A
options.text: It turns oxygen-18 into fluorine-18

options.label: B
options.text: It turns fluorine-18 into oxygen-18

options.label: C
options.text: It creates a positron emission

options.label: D
options.text: It produces a high-energy photon

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary use of FDG in PET scans?

options.label: A
options.text: To detect the spread of cancer

options.label: B
options.text: To diagnose Alzheimer's disease

options.label: C
options.text: To observe the location of an infection

options.label: D
options.text: To signal the presence of cancer, location of an infection, or slowing brain function of dementia

multiple-choice.question: What happens when a radiolabeled tracer enters the body and reaches its target?

options.label: A
options.text: It gets taken up by its target and the rest clears from circulation

options.label: B
options.text: It gets cleared from circulation and the target remains unaffected

options.label: C
options.text: It causes a nuclear reaction in which the mass of the two particles is converted into two high-energy photons

options.label: D
options.text: It produces a positron emission

multiple-choice.question: What is the result of the collision between a positron and an electron in the body?

options.label: A
options.text: A high-energy photon is produced

options.label: B
options.text: A nuclear reaction occurs in which the mass of the two particles is converted into two high-energy photons

options.label: C
options.text: A positron emission occurs

options.label: D
options.text: A high-energy photon and a positron are produced

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary purpose of a PET scanner?

options.label: A
options.text: To create a 3D map of the tracer's distribution

options.label: B
options.text: To detect the spread of cancer

options.label: C
options.text: To diagnose Alzheimer's disease

options.label: D
options.text: To observe the location of an infection

multiple-choice.question: What is the amount of radiation a patient receives during a PET scan comparable to?

options.label: A
options.text: The amount of radiation from natural radioactive sources over one year

options.label: B
options.text: The amount of radiation from natural radioactive sources over two or three years

options.label: C
options.text: The amount of radiation from cosmic radiation after 10 transatlantic flights

options.label: D
options.text: The amount of radiation from cosmic radiation after 20 to 30 transatlantic flights

options.label: D

options.label: C
options.text: The time you spend in the rain.

options.label: D
options.text: The distance you travel.

options.label: C

options.label: C

options.label: B

options.label: B

options.label: C

options.label: D
options.text: The wetness per meter for rain from the top times the number of meters you travel.

title: Can you solve the unstoppable blob riddle? - Dan Finkel

multiple-choice.question: What is the nature of the blob that has crashed on Earth?

options.label: A
options.text: It's a living creature that can grow and regenerate.

options.label: B
options.text: It's a machine that can be destroyed with conventional weapons.

options.label: C
options.text: It's a natural disaster that can be mitigated with technology.

options.label: D
options.text: It's a space debris that can be removed with a satellite.

multiple-choice.question: What is the blob's rate of growth?

options.label: A
options.text: It grows at a constant rate.

options.label: B
options.text: It doubles in size every hour.

options.label: C
options.text: It grows at a rate that can be slowed down with technology.

options.label: D
options.text: It doesn't grow at all.

multiple-choice.question: What is the blob's behavior when it's not growing?

options.label: A
options.text: It sleeps in a spherical shape.

options.label: B
options.text: It sleeps in a flat triangle shape.

options.label: C
options.text: It's active and continues to grow.

options.label: D
options.text: It's destroyed by conventional weapons.

multiple-choice.question: What happens when the blob is cut into two triangles?

options.label: A
options.text: Both triangles grow and regenerate.

options.label: B
options.text: Both triangles are inert and don't grow.

options.label: C
options.text: One triangle grows and regenerates, while the other is inert.

options.label: D
options.text: The triangles are destroyed by conventional weapons.

options.label: B
options.text: Obtuse triangle.

options.label: C
options.text: Right triangle.

options.label: D
options.text: Any triangle will grow and regenerate.

options.label: A
options.text: Cutting it into small pieces.

options.label: B
options.text: Cutting it into large pieces.

options.label: C
options.text: Cutting off the sharp corners to form a pentagon.

options.label: D
options.text: Using conventional weapons to destroy it.

multiple-choice.question: How many cuts are needed to cut the blob into acute triangles?

options.label: A
options.text: 1 cut.

options.label: B
options.text: 2 cuts.

options.label: C
options.text: 3 cuts.

options.label: D
options.text: 7 cuts.

multiple-choice.question: What is the advantage of cutting the blob into acute triangles?

options.label: A
options.text: It makes it easier to destroy with conventional weapons.

options.label: B
options.text: It makes it easier to grow and regenerate.

options.label: C
options.text: It makes it completely inert and unable to grow or regenerate.

options.label: D
options.text: It has no advantage.

multiple-choice.question: What inspired the solution to cutting the blob into acute triangles?

options.label: A
options.text: A pizza.

options.label: B
options.text: A machine.

options.label: C
options.text: A natural disaster.

options.label: D
options.text: A space debris.

multiple-choice.question: What is the outcome of cutting the blob into acute triangles?

options.label: A
options.text: The blob continues to grow and regenerate.

options.label: B
options.text: The blob is destroyed by conventional weapons.

options.label: C
options.text: The blob is completely inert and unable to grow or regenerate.

options.label: D
options.text: The blob is removed from the Earth.

options.text: Root pressure

title: How to connect with depressed friends - Bill Bernat

options.label: C
options.text: That it affects only 10% of the population.

options.label: A
options.text: Because they are afraid of being responsible for their well-being.

options.label: B
options.text: Because they don't know what to say.

options.label: C
options.text: Because they see them as flawed or defective.

options.label: D
options.text: All of the above.

options.label: A
options.text: "You're so strong for dealing with this."

options.label: B
options.text: "Just get over it."

options.label: C
options.text: "I'm here for you."

options.label: D
options.text: "You're not alone."

options.label: A
options.text: Because they are trying to manipulate you.

options.label: B
options.text: Because they are not taking their medication.

options.label: C
options.text: Because they are not listening to you.

options.label: D
options.text: Because they are not feeling well and need space.

multiple-choice.question: What is one thing that you can do to help a depressed person feel more comfortable around you?

options.text: Ask them to talk about their feelings.

options.label: B
options.text: Invite them to contribute to your life in some way.

options.label: C
options.text: Tell them to "just get over it."

options.label: D
options.text: Avoid talking to them altogether.

options.label: A
options.text: To focus on fixing their problems.

options.label: B
options.text: To focus on being upbeat and cheerful.

options.label: C
options.text: To focus on treating them with kindness and respect.

options.label: D
options.text: To focus on building a bridge between you.

options.label: A
options.text: She reached out and offered to help them in specific ways.

options.label: B
options.text: She told them to "just get over it."

options.label: C
options.text: She avoided talking to them altogether.

options.label: D
options.text: She focused on fixing their problems.

multiple-choice.question: What is the guiding principle that the speaker suggests should guide our interactions with depressed people?

options.label: A
options.text: To focus on fixing their problems.

options.label: B
options.text: To focus on being upbeat and cheerful.

options.label: C
options.text: To treat them with kindness and respect, and to see their life as valuable, intense, and beautiful.

title: How does the Rorschach inkblot test work? - Damion Searls

options.text: A series of images to test a person's creativity.

options.label: B
options.text: To gain new insight into the process of perception.

options.label: C
options.text: To test a person's intelligence.

options.label: D
options.text: To create a new form of art.

multiple-choice.question: How did Hermann Rorschach analyze the test-taker's responses?

options.label: B
options.text: By reducing the wide range of interpretations to a few manageable numbers.

options.label: C
options.text: By giving a score based on the time taken to complete the test.

options.label: D

options.label: B
options.text: It yielded real insights into their psychology.

options.label: C
options.text: It yielded insights into their physical health.

options.label: D
options.text: It yielded insights into their emotional intelligence.

options.label: C
options.text: It was used to test a person's intelligence.

options.label: D

options.label: C
options.text: The test was proven to be a reliable diagnostic tool.

options.label: D
options.text: The test was proven to be a useful tool for employers.

multiple-choice.question: What is the Rorschach Test still used for today?

options.label: B

options.label: C
options.text: It is used to test a person's intelligence.

options.label: D
options.text: It is used to administer a personality test.

multiple-choice.question: What is the Rorschach Test not used for?

options.label: A
options.text: It is not used to test a person's memory.

multiple-choice.question: What is the Rorschach Test's visual approach and lack of a single right answer used for?

options.label: A
options.text: It is used to test a person's creativity.

options.label: B

options.label: C
options.text: It is used to test a person's intelligence.

title: Can you solve the jail break riddle? - Dan Finkel

multiple-choice.question: How can you use the fuses and lighter to time exactly 45 seconds?

options.label: A

options.label: B
options.text: By lighting one end of a fuse and waiting for it to burn out, then lighting one end of a second fuse.

options.label: C
options.text: By lighting both ends of a fuse simultaneously and waiting for it to burn out, then lighting one end of a second fuse.

options.label: D
options.text: If you light a fuse from both ends simultaneously, it will burn out in precisely 30 seconds.

options.label: C
options.text: By using a 15-second fuse and lighting one end of it at the same time as you light the first fuse.

options.label: D
options.text: By using a 45-second fuse and lighting one end of it at the same time as you light the first fuse.

title: Three ways the universe could end - Venus Keus

multiple-choice.question: What is the Big Bang theory?

options.label: A
options.text: A theory that the universe is expanding at an accelerated rate.

options.label: B
options.text: A theory that all matter, time, and space began in an incredibly tiny, compact state about 14 billion years ago.

options.label: C
options.text: A theory that the universe is getting smaller and smaller.

options.label: D
options.text: A theory that the universe is static and unchanging.

options.label: A
options.text: A scenario where the force of gravity brings the universe's expansion to a halt and then reverses it.

options.label: B
options.text: A scenario where the expansion of the universe continues to accelerate, tearing apart galaxies and solar systems.

options.label: C
options.text: A scenario where the universe becomes darker and colder, approaching a frozen state.

options.label: D
options.text: A scenario where the universe gets smaller and smaller.

multiple-choice.question: What is the Big Crunch scenario?

options.label: A
options.text: A scenario where the universe becomes darker and colder, approaching a frozen state.

options.label: B
options.text: A scenario where the force of gravity brings the universe's expansion to a halt and then reverses it.

options.label: C
options.text: A scenario where the universe gets smaller and smaller.

options.label: D
options.text: A scenario where the universe expands and contracts over and over again.

multiple-choice.question: What is the Big Bounce theory?

options.label: A
options.text: A theory that the universe will expand and contract over and over again, repeating its entire history.

options.label: B
options.text: A theory that the universe will become darker and colder, approaching a frozen state.

options.label: C
options.text: A theory that the universe will get smaller and smaller.

options.label: D
options.text: A theory that the universe is static and unchanging.

options.label: B

options.label: C

options.label: D
options.text: That we're heading for a Big Bounce.

options.text: 100 to the 100th power years

options.label: A

options.label: B

options.label: C
options.text: I am sad to see you.

options.label: D
options.text: I am angry to see you.

options.text: She expressed her grief openly and received support from her family.

options.label: B
options.text: She suppressed her grief and used food to numb her pain.

options.label: C
options.text: She wrote about her grief in a journal and received guidance from her teacher.

options.label: D
options.text: She denied her grief and pretended everything was fine.

multiple-choice.question: What did the author's eighth-grade English teacher ask her to do?

options.label: A
options.text: To write a story about her favorite book.

options.label: B
options.text: To write what she was feeling and tell the truth.

options.label: C
options.text: To draw a picture of her family.

options.label: D
options.text: To write a poem about her emotions.

multiple-choice.question: What is the conventional view of emotions that the author disagrees with?

options.label: A
options.text: That emotions are a natural part of life.

options.label: B
options.text: That emotions are good or bad, positive or negative.

options.label: C
options.text: That emotions are a personal choice.

options.label: D
options.text: That emotions are a result of external factors.

multiple-choice.question: What is the result of pushing aside normal emotions to embrace false positivity?

options.label: A
options.text: We become more resilient and able to deal with challenges.

options.label: B
options.text: We lose our capacity to develop skills to deal with the world as it is.

options.label: C
options.text: We become more confident and self-assured.

options.label: D
options.text: We become more empathetic and understanding.

multiple-choice.question: What is the difference between saying "I am" and "I'm noticing that I'm feeling"?

options.label: A
options.text: Saying "I am" makes you sound more confident, while saying "I'm noticing that I'm feeling" makes you sound more vulnerable.

options.label: B
options.text: Saying "I am" makes you sound like you are the emotion, while saying "I'm noticing that I'm feeling" makes you sound like you are observing the emotion.

options.label: C
options.text: Saying "I am" makes you sound more anxious, while saying "I'm noticing that I'm feeling" makes you sound more relaxed.

options.label: D
options.text: Saying "I am" makes you sound more sad, while saying "I'm noticing that I'm feeling" makes you sound more happy.

options.label: A

options.label: B
options.text: A fear of emotions.

options.label: C
options.text: A suppression of emotions.

options.label: D
options.text: A denial of emotions.

multiple-choice.question: What does emotional agility allow us to do?

options.label: A
options.text: To avoid difficult emotions.

options.label: B
options.text: To be with our emotions with curiosity, compassion, and courage.

options.label: C
options.text: To suppress our emotions.

options.label: D
options.text: To deny our emotions.

options.label: A
options.text: That fear is something to be avoided.

options.label: B
options.text: That courage is not the absence of fear, but fear walking.

options.label: C
options.text: That fear is something to be suppressed.

options.label: D
options.text: That fear is something to be denied.

multiple-choice.question: What is the author's message to the audience at the end of the talk?

options.label: A
options.text: To always be positive and avoid difficult emotions.

options.label: B
options.text: To be agile and face our fragility with courage.

options.label: C
options.text: To suppress our emotions and pretend everything is fine.

options.label: D
options.text: To deny our emotions and avoid reality.

options.text: A person who lives in multiple countries.

options.label: B
options.text: A person who has multiple identities.

options.label: C
options.text: A person who has multiple sets of experiences.

options.label: D
options.text: A person who is connected to multiple cultures.

options.label: A
options.text: The importance of national identity.

options.label: B
options.text: The importance of locality.

options.label: C
options.text: The importance of human experience.

options.label: D
options.text: The importance of culture.

title: The disarming case to act right now on climate change - Greta Thunberg

multiple-choice.question: What was the speaker's initial reaction to hearing about climate change at the age of 8?

options.label: A
options.text: They were very interested and wanted to learn more.

options.label: B
options.text: They thought it was too unreal and didn't add up.

options.label: C
options.text: They were scared and didn't know what to do.

options.label: D
options.text: They thought it was just a normal part of life.

options.label: A
options.text: They had asthma and eczema.

options.label: B
options.text: They had depression, Asperger syndrome, OCD, and selective mutism.

options.label: C

options.label: D
options.text: They had a broken leg and a concussion.

multiple-choice.question: What is the speaker's perspective on the sustainability crisis?

options.label: A
options.text: They think it's an existential threat and the most important issue of all.

options.label: B
options.text: They think it's not a big deal and we can just carry on as usual.

options.label: C
options.text: They think it's a normal part of life and we should just adapt.

options.label: D
options.text: They think it's too complicated and we can't do anything about it.

multiple-choice.question: What does the speaker think is the main reason people don't take action on climate change?

options.label: A
options.text: They think it's because people are not aware of the consequences of their actions.

options.label: B
options.text: They think it's because people are too lazy to make changes.

options.label: C
options.text: They think it's because people are too busy to care.

options.label: D
options.text: They think it's because people are not willing to make sacrifices.

options.label: A
options.text: They organized a protest march.

options.label: B
options.text: They started a petition.

options.label: C
options.text: They set themselves down on the ground outside the Swedish parliament and school struck for the climate.

options.label: D
options.text: They wrote a letter to their local government.

options.label: A

options.label: B
options.text: They think we need to switch to renewable energy sources.

options.label: C
options.text: They think we need to change our behavior and make sacrifices.

options.label: D
options.text: They think we need to hope for the best and wait for someone else to solve the problem.

title: How do ocean currents work? - Jennifer Verduin

multiple-choice.question: What event in 1992 led to a better understanding of ocean currents?

options.label: A
options.text: A massive earthquake

options.label: B
options.text: A cargo ship carrying bath toys got caught in a storm

options.label: C
options.text: A volcanic eruption

options.label: D
options.text: A hurricane

multiple-choice.question: What are the two main categories of ocean currents?

options.label: A
options.text: Surface and deep ocean currents

options.label: B
options.text: Tidal and wind-driven currents

options.label: C
options.text: Warm and cold ocean currents

options.label: D
options.text: Freshwater and saltwater currents

multiple-choice.question: What drives surface currents near the shore?

options.label: A
options.text: Wind and tides

options.label: B
options.text: Wind and changes in water density

options.label: C
options.text: Tides and the rotation of the Earth

options.label: D
options.text: Wind and the Coriolis Effect

multiple-choice.question: What is the Coriolis Effect?

options.label: A
options.text: The way the Earth's rotation affects the wind patterns that give rise to surface currents

options.label: B
options.text: The way the wind affects the rotation of the Earth

options.label: C
options.text: The way the ocean affects the wind patterns

options.label: D
options.text: The way the tides affect the wind patterns

multiple-choice.question: What is thermohaline circulation?

options.label: A
options.text: The movement of water due to changes in the density of seawater

options.label: B
options.text: The movement of water due to wind and tides

options.label: C
options.text: The movement of water due to the Coriolis Effect

options.label: D
options.text: The movement of water due to changes in the rotation of the Earth

multiple-choice.question: What is the Global Conveyor Belt?

options.label: A
options.text: A winding loop of thermohaline circulation and wind-driven surface currents

options.label: B
options.text: A straight line of thermohaline circulation and wind-driven surface currents

options.label: C
options.text: A circle of thermohaline circulation and wind-driven surface currents

options.label: D
options.text: A square of thermohaline circulation and wind-driven surface currents

multiple-choice.question: What is the purpose of the Global Conveyor Belt?

options.label: A
options.text: To distribute warmth around the globe

options.label: B
options.text: To distribute nutrients to the ocean food chains

options.label: C
options.text: To distribute salt and freshwater around the globe

options.label: D
options.text: To distribute wind and tides around the globe

multiple-choice.question: What is the effect of rising sea temperatures on the Global Conveyor Belt?

options.label: A
options.text: It causes the conveyor belt to speed up

options.label: B
options.text: It causes the conveyor belt to slow down

options.label: C
options.text: It has no effect on the conveyor belt

options.label: D
options.text: It causes the conveyor belt to stop altogether
